[[File:Daphne Akhurst Memorial Cup (Australian Open - Women's single).svg|thumb|right|100px|The Daphne Akhurst Memorial Cup]]

'''Daphne Jessie Akhurst''' (22 April 1903 – 9 January 1933) known also by her married name '''Daphne Cozens''', was an Australian [[tennis]] player.

Akhurst won the women's singles title at the [[Australian Open|Australian Championships]] five times between 1925 and 1930. According to Wallis Myers (''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', ''[[Daily Mail]]''), she was ranked World No. 3 in 1928.<ref>{{cite book|author=Collins, Bud|title=The Bud Collins History of Tennis: An Authoritative Encyclopedia and Record Book|publisher=New Chapter Press|location=New York|year=2008|pages=695, 701|isbn=978-0-942257-41-0}}</ref>

==Career==
The second daughter of Oscar James Akhurst, a lithographer, and his wife Jessie Florence (née Smith), Daphne Akhurst won the women's singles title at the [[Australian Open|Australian Championships]] five times, in 1925, 1926, 1928, 1929, and 1930. She is fourth on the list of most women's singles titles at the Australian Championships; behind only [[Margaret Court]] with eleven titles, [[Serena Williams]] with seven and [[Nancye Wynne Bolton]] with six titles. She won the women's doubles title at the Australian Championships five times: in 1924 and 1925 with [[Sylvia Lance Harper]], in 1928 with [[Esna Boyd|Esna Boyd Robertson]], and in 1929 and 1931 with [[Louie Bickerton]]. She and [[Marjorie Cox Crawford|Marjorie Cox]] were the runners-up in 1926. {{Citation needed|date=July 2012}}

In 1925 she was part of the first Australian women's team to tour Europe and reached the quarterfinal of the singles event at [[1925 Wimbledon Championships|Wimbledon]] which she lost to [[Joan Fry]].<ref name=themercury/> During her second and last European tour in 1928, she reached the singles quarterfinal at the French Championships, in which Cristobel Hardie defeated her, and the semifinal at Wimbledon, which she lost in straight sets to [[Lili de Alvarez]].

Akhurst won the mixed doubles title at the Australian Championships four times: in 1924 and 1925 with [[James Willard|Jim Willard]], in 1928 with [[Jean Borotra]], and in 1929 with [[Gar Moon]]. She and Willard were the runners-up in 1926. She and her partner [[Jack Crawford (tennis)|Jack Crawford]] reached the mixed doubles final at [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] in 1928, but lost to the team of [[Elizabeth Ryan]]/[[Patrick Spence]], 7–5, 6–4.

Akhurst won the singles title at the [[German Open (WTA)|German Championships]] in 1928 after a three-sets victory in the final against defending champion [[Cilly Aussem]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article79481290 |title=Remarkable Performance |newspaper=[[Daily News (Perth, Western Australia)|The Daily News]] |volume=XLVII |issue=16,625 |location=Western Australia |date=13 August 1928 |page=1 (Home (final) edition) |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Akhurst attended the Miss. E. Tildesley's [[Normanhurst School, Ashfield|Normanhurst School]], followed by the [[Sydney Conservatorium of Music]].<ref name=grasso>{{cite book|last1=Grasso|first1=John|title=Historical Dictionary of Tennis|url=https://archive.org/details/historicaldictio00gras|url-access=limited|date=2011|publisher=Scarecrow Press|location=Lanham, Maryland|isbn=978-0810872370|page=[https://archive.org/details/historicaldictio00gras/page/n46 22]}}</ref> On 26 February 1930 at [[St Philip's Church, Sydney|St Philip's Church of England]], Sydney, Daphne Akhurst married Royston Stuckey Cozens, a tobacco manufacturer, and retired from serious competition soon after winning the Australian ladies' doubles championship in 1931. They had one son, Don. Daphne Akhurst Cozens died on 9 January 1933, aged 29, from an [[ectopic pregnancy]] and was cremated.<ref name=themercury>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article24725162 |title=Mrs. Roy Cozens |newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart, Tas. |date=11 January 1933 |page=9 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>

==Legacy==
Since 1934 the trophy presented each year to the winner of the women's singles at the Australian Open is named the ''Daphne Akhurst Memorial Cup'' in her honour.<ref name=grasso/> She was inducted into the [[Australian Tennis Hall of Fame]] on Australia Day (26 January), 2006.<ref>{{cite web|title=Player Profiles – Daphne Akhurst|url=http://www.tennis.com.au/player-profiles/daphne-akhurst|publisher=Tennis Australia|accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> She was inducted into the [[International Tennis Hall of Fame]] in 2013.
